body.p: A Kentucky attorney, politician, and minister. Served in the Mexican War as a second lieutenant as a part of the First Kentucky Cavalry. Graduated from Transylvania University in 1849 and from the law department in 1852. Admitted to the bar 1852. Practiced law in Covington, Kentucky in partnership with his father John Speed Smith. Married to Lena Duke Smith. Father of Eliza Clay Smith Hawkins, Mary Buford Smith, Keith Duke Smith, Lena Duke Smith, and Green Clay Smith, Jr. Served as school commissioner from 1853 to 1857 in Madison County, Kentucky. Elected as a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives from 1861 to 1863. Served in the Civil War as a colonel in the Fourth Regiment, Kentucky Volunteer Calvary and as a brigadier general and brevetted major general of Volunteers. Served the Sixth Congressional District of Kentucky as an Unconditional Unionist member of the United States House of Representative from 1863 to 1866. Served as a delegate to the National Union Party Convention at Baltimore, Maryland, in 1864. Appointed and served as governor of the Montana Territory from 1866 to 1869.
